title-group.article-title: Title: Effectiveness and safety of pirfenidone for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
Objectives:
abstract.p: To assess the long-term effectiveness of pirfenidone in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) treatment and to establish its adverse effects profile.
abstract.title: Methods:
abstract.p: Retrospective observational study in patients with IPF who initiated treatment with pirfenidone between 2011 and 2016. We collected demographic variables (age, sex); date of first and last treatment; reason for discontinuation; pulmonary function measures (forced vital capacity [(FVC] ), carbon monoxide diffusion capacity [(DLCO] ), and 6 min walk test [(6MWT])) at treatment initiation (baseline) and at one1-, two-2, and three3 year follow-up; adherence to pirfenidone treatment; recorded adverse effects; and mortality.
abstract.title: Results:
abstract.p: 31Thirty-one patients treated with pirfenidone were included; mean (± standard deviationSD) age was 69 (± 8) years, 74 % were men, and 59 % had a smoking history. Mean baseline values were: for FVC, 2.43 ± 0.66 L (61.8 % ± 12.1 %); DLCO, 46.1 % ± 19.4 %; and 6MWT, 334 ± 125 m. Median duration of treatment was 14 ± 13 months, and treatment was discontinued in 58 % of patients. The most frequently observed adverse effects were gastrointestinal disturbances and photosensitivity. Twenty (65%) patients were evaluated at one1 year, when mean FVC was 2.41 ± 0.86 L (64.7 % ± 20.3 %); DLCO, 50.8 % ± 26.8 %; and 6MWT, 341 ± 139 m. At two2 years ’ follow-up, 11 patients (36%) who were still taking pirfenidone were evaluated. Mean FVC was 2.34 ± 0.79 L (66.2 % ± 14.7 %); DLCO, 50.0 % ± 28.3 %; and 6MWT, 265 ± 121 m. At three3 years, five patients were still taking the treatment. Mean FVC was 2.71 ± 0.84 L (71.0 % ± 24.7 %); DLCO, 52.6 % ± 26.7 %,; and 6MWT, 286 ± 139 m. Nineteen per cent19 % of patients were not n-adherent to treatment.
abstract.title: Conclusions:
abstract.p: Pirfenidone seems to be effective for long-term control of IPF despite substantial variability in response among individual patients. The most frequent adverse effects were digestive and cutaneous, prompting in some cases a reduction in dose or even discontinuation of the treatment.

funding-group.funding-statement: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

p.data-style: font-family: 'Calibri',sans-serif; font-size: 11.0pt; margin-left: 3.0pt; margin-right: 0cm; line-height: 115%; margin-bottom: 10.0pt; margin-top: 0cm;

body.p: 2667 words
30 references
EFFECTIVENESS AND SAFETY OF PIRFENIDONE FOR IDIOPATHIC PULMONARY FIBROSIS

boxed-text.title: What is already known on this subject:

list-item.p: · The use of pirfenidone has been demonstrated shown to be a therapeutic approach to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis that is able to slow the progression of the disease in its earlier stages.
· Further studies about its use in a long- term and in a real-world environinvolvement weare needed.

boxed-text.title: What this study adds:

list-item.p: · Pirfenidone could be an effectiveness option to stabilizestabilise the course of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis in a long-term treatment.

body.p: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a rare disease with unknown etiologyaetiology and poor prognosis, characterizedcharacterised by the gradual fibrosis of the pulmonary interstitium. Its clinical course is variable, but the disease is associated with high morbimortality.1 Prevalence is estimated at 3 to 9 cases per 100 000 people,2 and mean survival is 2two to five5 years from onset of symptoms.3 There are few therapeutic options; the only treatment that leads to a substantial improvement in function and survival is a lung transplant. Failing that, currently available drug treatments (pirfenidone and nintedanib) aim to stabilizestabilise the course of the disease or at least slow the speed of its progression.4

The European Medicines Agency (EMA)approved pirfenidone in February 2011 for the treatment of mild to moderate IPF, defined as forced vital capacity (FVC) of 50% or more and carbon monoxide diffusion capacity (DLCO) of 35% or more. Pirfenidone has anti-inflammatory, antifibrotic, and antioxidant properties5 that have proven beneficial for slowing the progression of IPF and the deterioration of FVC, and for improving mortality outcomes; however, the drug may also cause adverse effects that lead to discontinuation of treatment, mainly gastrointestinal problems such as nausea, vomiting, and dyspepsia.4 6 7

This study aims to assess the long-term effectiveness of pirfenidone for treating IPF and to establish its adverse effects profile in patients receiving treatment in a tertiary hospital. Primary outcomes were related to lung function (FVC and DLCO), measured over three3 years from the start of treatment. Secondary outcomes were also measured over three3 years: (a) adverse effects; (b) rate of treatment discontinuation; (c) reasons for treatment discontinuation; (d) mortality in patients receiving treatment; (e) exercise capacity, measured using the 6 min walk test (6MWT); and (f) short-term evolution of lung function (FVC and DLCO) and exercise capacity (6MWT), using 1one- and two2 year follow-up as intermediate time points.

This was a retrospective observational study in patients with IPF who were started on pirfenidone treatment from 2011 to December 2016. We included all patients with IPF whose clinical records included baseline measures (ie, at treatment initiation) for FVC, DLCO and 6MWT. As pPirfenidone’s data sheet indicates this drug tfor the treatment of mild to moderate IPF, our patients had, at the time they started pirfenidone, FVC ≥50% and DLCO ≥35%. We collected the following data: demographic variables (age, sex, comorbidities); date of initiation and end of treatment; reason for discontinuing treatment; lung function tests (FVC and DLCO as absolute values and as the relative percentage compared tocompared with the reference values established by formulae described in existing clinical practice guidelines) and exercise test (6MWT) at baseline, one-1, two-,2 and three3 year follow-up; adherence to pirfenidone treatment, measured according to hospital pharmacy dispensing records (patients who stopped collecting their prescriptions from the hospital pharmacy were considered non-adherent); adverse effects; and mortality.

To evaluate the qualitative evolution of the disease with regard to FVC (predicted values), we defined stability between assessment time points as a variation of up to 10% from the previously recorded value. Values that increased by >more than 10% were considered improvements, and those that decreased by >more than 10% were considered to show worsening. For DLCO (predicted values), the reference value to define stability, improvement, or worsening was 15%. For 6MWT, 50 m was the cutoffcut-off for establishing differences.

All statistical analyses were performed with SPSS software (version 25.0). Continuous data were recorded as mean±SD. The Shapiro-Wilk test was used to test for normality of these data. Lung function values were compared through time with the Mann-Whitney U test.
body.title: Demographic characteristics
body.p: We included 31 patients (74% men; 59% haved a smoking history) with a mean age of 69±8 years. Complete information on the baseline demographic characteristics of our patients is provided inas a supplementary table.online supplementary file 1. Mean baseline values were: for FVC, 2.43±0.66 L (61.8%±12.1%); DLCO, 46.1%±19.4%; and 6MWT, 334±125 m (Table 1table 1). Median length of time between IPF diagnosis and the start ofn pirfenidone treatment was 13.61±15.22 months. Median duration of pirfenidone treatment was 14±13 months at study end, by which time treatment had been discontinued in 18 (58%) patients (1–49 months). These patients stopped treatment due to digestive complaints (39%), death (28%), treatment inefficacy (17%), photosensitivity (11%), and non-adherence (5%).

caption.title: Baseline lung function and exercise values.

body.p: Figure 1 represents mean FVC in patients throughout time. Lung function measured as FVC remains without any no statistically significant change at the end of the 3 years observational period. In addition, no changes were observed at the intermediate points of evaluation (one1 and two2 years). Table 2Table 2 summarizessummarises all the data on lung function and exercise capacity in the patients throughout the study period.

title.named-content: Mean forced vital capacity (%FVC) throughout the 3 year observational period.

caption.title: Evolution of lung function and exercise capacity over follow-up.

fn.p: The change from baseline is refferred to the change from the baseline of the patients assessed.

body.title: Primary outcomes
body.p: At three3 years, five patients were still taking the treatment. Mean FVC was 2.71±0.84 L (71.0%±24.7%); DLCO, 52.6%±26.7%,; and 6MWT, 286±139 m. Change from baseline for FVC was +0.01±0.36 L (+8.8%±18.1%); forDLCO, +7.4%±21.9%;, and for6MWT,+21±129 m. For FVC, there was a qualitative improvement in 40% of cases and stabilizationstabilisation in 60%; for DLCO, improvement in 20% and stabilizationstabilisation in 80%; and for 6MWT, improvement in 60%, stabilizationstabilisation in 20%, and worsening in 20%. Nineteen per cent of patients were notn -adherent to treatment.
body.title: Secondary outcomes
body.p: At three3 years, eight (26%) patients had died, all of them due to respiratory causes. Pirfenidone treatment had been stopped in two of these cases due to lack of efficacy. Table 3Table 3 analyszes mean FVC at baseline and each year comparing survivors and non-survivors. As seen inthis table shows, mean FVC at any time was lower in dead patients who died than in survivors, but it only had statistical significance in the first year of treatment.

caption.title: Statistical analysis of survivors versus non-survivors FVC at baseline and throughout time.

fn.p: Significance p<0,.05 (CI 95% CI). A non-survivor was a patient who died at any time.

body.p: Table 4Ttable 4 compares mean FVC at baseline and yearly in patients who discontinued pirfenidone and patients who did not. As expected, those who discontinued pirfenidone had a lower FVC at baseline and every following year than those who continued pirfenidone. This fact appeared to be more relevant in patients at the baseline and in the first year of treatment.

caption.title: Statistical analysis of drop-outs Statistical analysis of Ddrop-outs versus non-dropouts FVC throughout time.

fn.p: Significance p<0,.05 (CI 95% CI). A drop-out was a patient who discontinued pirfenidone at any time.

body.p: Six of the 31 (19%) patients were non-adherent. All of these patients stopped treatment, in 67% of the cases due to adverse effects: three patients experienced gastrointestinal disorders and one, patient experienced phototoxicity. In one case, the patient stopped treatment due to perceived inefficacy, and the other became non-adherent after reducing the dosage following adverse gastrointestinal effects.

Table 5Ttable 5 shows the adverse effects reported in the patients as well as the treatment modifications arising from them. There were a total 45 adverse effects, or an average of 1.45 per patient. Ten (22%) effects led to a reduction in dose, and 16 (35%) prompted the definitive discontinuation of treatment. Regarding short-term evolution of lung function and exercise capacity, results at intermediate time points were as follows.

caption.title: Adverse reactions to treatment and subsequent dosage adjustment

body.p: Twenty (65%) patients were followed up at one1 year, when mean FVC was 2.41±0.86 L (64.7%±20.3%); DLCO, 50.8%±26.8%; and 6MWT, 341±139 m. Mean change from baseline for FVC was −0.05±0.38 L (+2.7%±12.1%); forDLCO, +3.6%±13.4%; and for6MWT, +2±99 m. Qualitative measures were: for FVC, improvement in 30% of patients, stabilizationstabilisation in 60%, and worsening in 10%; for DLCO, improvement in 50%, stabilizationstabilisation in 45%, and worsening in 5%; and for 6MWT, improvement in 15%, stabilizationstabilisation in 70%, and worsening in 15%.

At two2 years’ follow-up, 11 patients (36%) who were still taking pirfenidone were evaluated. Mean FVC was 2.34±0.79 L (66.2%±14.7%); DLCO, 50.0%±28.3%; and 6MWT, 265±121 m. Change from baseline for FVC was −0.04±0.29 L (+2.2%±13.0%); for DLCO, +4.2%±17.9%; and for6MWT, −63±121 m. Qualitative indicators for FVC showed improvement in 18% of patients and stabilizationstabilisation in 82%; for DLCO: improvement in 18%, stabilizationstabilisation in 73%, and worsening in 9%; and for 6MWT: improvement in 27%, stabilizationstabilisation in 18%, and worsening in 55%.

Historically, treatment of IPF has focused on the use of anti-inflammatory and immunomodulating agents, but data supporting this approach were weak. A Ddefinitive answer to the use of these agents was provided by the PANTHER- IPFP study. It was a randomizedrandomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial of IPF patients randomizedrandomised to prednisone+azathioprine and N-aAcetylcysteine (NAC), NAC alone, or placebo. Increased rate of hospitalizationhospitalisation and death was found in the combination group when compared tocompared with the placebo group, leading to definitive advice against their use.6

Another past treatment for IPF patients was NAC in monotherapy, as its antioxidant properties wasere thought to provide some benefits in the disease. Again, data supporting its use were weak. A Ddefinitive answer was provided by the NAC arm of the PANTHER-IPF study, demonstrating that NAC was not effective in slowing down the rate of progression of the disease.7 A decrease in FVC is the best predictor of imminent mortality in this disease,8–10 with patients showing a decrease in FVC of 10% or more over 24 weeks having a 4.8-fold greater risk of death at one1 year; in those with a 5%– to 10% decrease, the risk of death is 2.1 times higher.11 For that reason, the international guidelines for IPF consider an absolute decrease of 10% of FVC to be evidence of significant disease progression.1 Nevertheless, neither this 10% reduction nor admission to hospital necessarily indicate treatment failure with pirfenidone, with some data indicating that continuing treatment in these cases reduces the risk for continued deterioration of FVC or death at six6 months.12 Similarly, diminished FVC has been shown to be a predictor for early mortality but not future deterioration of FVC.12 Another predictor of mortality was a decrease of 15% or more in DLCO over 6 to 12 months, so this measure is also considered a criterion of disease progression.13

The use of aAntifibrotic drugs, such as pirfenidone, was a definitive milestone in the management of IPF. Pirfenidone has slowed disease progression and has decreased mortality compared with placebo in the phase III clinical trials.14 15 Before effective treatments had been used, median survival of patients with IPF was only 2 to 3 years (with only 20–% to 30% of subjects alive 5 years after diagnosis), and mean annual rate of decline in FVC rangesd from 150 mL to 200 mL.16 17 This reduction tends to be smaller under pirfenidone treatment.

Long-term data ofn the effectiveness of pirfenidone is available from the RECAP trial, with an annualizedannualised rate of FVC decline of 144±6.0 mL, a mean change in percent predicted FVC at 180 weeks of −9.6%, and a median survival of 77.2 months from the beginning of the treatment.18

In a randomizedrandomised trial, the annual reduction in FVC was 80 mL– to 90 mL.19 In a retrospective multicentrer study, mean FVC decreased by just 30 mL in the first year and then by an average of 158 mL and 201 mL in the second and third year, respectively,20 suggesting that the benefits of pirfenidone treatment are limited to the first year. More recent studies in a clinical practice setting point to an attenuation in the degree of annual reduction of FVC. Some compare results with measures taken beforeprior to initiation of treatment, confirming this trend.21–23 Another multicentrer study performed in Denmark confirmsed that pirfenidone lessened the mean reduction in parameters such as the FVC, DLCO and 6MWT, helping to maintain change scores below the thresholds established for clinically significant disease progression.24 In a study in China, mean FVC and DLCO values had improved by 3,.5% and 1,.1% in the first 6 months while controls worsened theise values by 2,.3% and 4,.7%;, although this improvement was lost after a year, but it still stabilizedstabilised lung function.25

Another important “‘real-world”’ study, conducted was done in Greece., This studydemonstrated functional improvement and functional stabilizationstabilisation for a large group of patients in the first three3 years of treatment with pirfenidone.26 The same group of authors tried to demonstrate that pirfenidone could be used in patients with severe IPF, and pirfenidone decreased functional decline compared tocompared with 6 months before treatment initiation, but this benefit did not last for one1 year after initiation.27

It is remarkable in our population tThe high length of time between IPF diagnosis and pirfenidone use is remarkable in our population. Patients included were diagnosed ofwith IPF during the period 2008–2016, but pirfenidone was not officially approved in Spain for IPF until late 2014. Before 2014, most of our patients wasere using other available treatments, such as like prednisone or azathioprine. Pirfenidone was available for the first time in Spain in 2011, when it could be requested in a compassionate use programprogramme,. which accounts So that was the reason for the delay in beginning treatment . In the present study, our patients receivingunder pirfenidone had a significantly smaller mean annual reduction in FVC, of up to 50 mL,, than in the majority of patients in of the above cited studies,, of up to a 50 mL , with similar change scores even at three3 years among thepatients who continued treatment in the long term. Furthermore, mean functional parameters had slightly increased in our patients after 1a year, two2 years,and three3 years of treatment. In our population we could corroborate that lung function tended to stabilizestabilise through the years in most patients, as previously seen[26)].26 . During a an up to 3 yearsfollow-up period of up to 3 years, minor changes awere observed in lung function in our IPF patients. These minor changes are very relevant from a clinical point of view.

Adverse effects were the most common reason for discontinuing treatment, which is consistent with findings from similar studies.20 The most frequent effects in our population were gastrointestinal and cutaneous, with values similar to those reported in the CAPACITY study14 and in studies similar to ours.21 24 26 We also obtained similar adverse effects to thosethan in a recent safety study.28 In some cases, adverse effects could be controlled with a reduction in dose, and in others treatment had to be stopped altogether. Once an adverse effect appears, the dose adjustment leads to a smaller percentage of patients who have to stop treatment due to adverse effects and alsoother causes, including death.29

We measured adherence using the hospital pharmacy outpatient dispensing registry. This method reveals which patients are collecting their prescriptions on time, allowing inferences regarding adherence. The administration of pirfenidone follows a complex dosing regimen, starting with an initial period to build up tolerance, followed by a maintenance period with three daily doses of three capsules each. Given this complexity, and the fact that treatment mainly occurs in thea context of polypharmacy, real adherence could be lower than that reflected in the hospital dispensing records.

Data from this study seem to indicate that pirfenidone has a positive effect by stabilizingstabilising (and even improving) the natural course of IPF, even if the predicted trend would be a slight worsening of function. This is consistent with data from pivotal studies and real-world studies. Now theefforts are focused on the development of new drugs and targets that allow to improvethese health outcomes to be improved.30 However, the study does have certain limitations, chief among them the retrospective collection of data, which in the case of aspects like drug adherence did not permit us to obtain real data but only absolute non-adherence data. Another important limitation was the small sample size, which makes it difficult to draw firm conclusions regarding the effectiveness of the drug, especially in light of the high variation in individual responses. The one-centercentre model was also a major flaw.

In our population, pirfenidone managed to stabilizestabilise lung function, as measured by both FVC and DLCO, in all patients who took it for the whole three3 year follow-up period. Aerobic capacity and endurance, as measured in the 6MWT, worsened in 20% of the patients treated at three3 years, although it remained stable or improved in the rest of the patients. Pirfenidone was generally well tolerated, despite the need to adjust the dose in some cases. The main adverse effects were gastrointestinal, followed by cutaneous effects. These reactions were the main reason for discontinuing treatment. During the study period, 26% of the patients died, all of them due to respiratory causes; this outcome was most apparent at two2 years. At the intermediate time points (1one and two2 years after initiation of treatment), lung function improved or stabilizedstabilised in most of the patients. Regarding the exercise test, the 6MWT showed a reduction in aerobic capacity and endurance at two2 years in most of the patients assessed (55%).
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS AND AFILLIATIONS
The authors declare no competing interests.

email-content.mail-subject: Proof of your article for European Journal of Hospital Pharmacy - 10.1136/ejhpharm-2018-001806

mail-body.p: I’m pleased to provide the proof of your article, which is available on our author proofing system here:

Please submit any corrections then ensure you click ‘Approve’ to complete the author proofing process. Signing off the paper will send the article back to the Production team so they can make any changes.
Please note, the online author proofing system cannot be used in the browser Internet Explorer. Please review your proofs in Google Chrome.

A PDF version of the proof is available to download and review, but all corrections must be submitted using the online system. Please contact us at production.ejhp@bmj.com if you need any help using this.

This is the only opportunity you will have to correct your article before publication, so please review it carefully. Please ensure you respond to queries listed in the article. Minor errors cannot be corrected after publication and any serious scientific errors will result in a formal correction.
Reprints: If you wish to purchase reprints of your article, please fill in the reprint form.
European Journal of Hospital Pharmacy Production Team
